description: An early touchscreen Alcatel phone which combines a phone with organizer features of a PDA.
A basic and easy-to-use Alcatel phone which could be used with AA batteries.
A compact Alcatel phone with WAP and polyphonic ringtone support.
An Alcatel phone with a 12-bit colour screen and a fun design.
A candy bar phone manufactured by Toshiba and released by Audiovox.
A candy bar phone by Toshiba and Audiovox with tri-mode network support.
A Toshiba/Audiovox phone featuring a large screen with WAP internet access.
A flip phone manufactured by Toshiba and released by Audiovox. Sports a large colour display.
A flip phone manufactured by Toshiba and released by Audiovox. Their first to support video recording.
A BlackBerry phone supporting iDEN networks and Java applications.
A BlackBerry phone featuring a SureType keypad with a 5x4 layout.
A BlackBerry phone featuring a SureType keypad with a 5x4 layout.
A business QWERTY phone and the first BlackBerry with EDGE data connectivity.
An iconic slide-out QWERTY messaging phone. Also known as the T-Mobile Sidekick.
An upgraded version of the original Hiptop/Sidekick with a camera, thinner body, and more.
A durable and affordable Ericsson phone which has exchangeable face plates.
An Ericsson phone with a WAP browser, built-in games and exchangeable covers.
The first device to be considered a smartphone. The keyboard flip opens to reveal a touchscreen.
A popular flip cover Ericsson phone which was available in various colors.
A small and lightweight Ericsson phone, their first featuring a colour screen. It had a camera attachment.
A Windows Mobile phone which was available on AT&T. Features include a large screen and 1MP camera.
A Windows Mobile smartphone featuring a slide-out QWERTY keyboard and 3G support.
An early 3G smart flip phone running Palm OS, powered by a DragonBall CPU.
An early Japanese smartphone with a monochrome screen.
A mid-range Kyocera phone and their first slider phone. Has BREW and high-speed data support.
An early phone from LG. Very similar to the TP-5250, but sports a unique neck strap.
A basic monochrome LG phone which uses 8-chord polyphonic ringtones.
One of the most popular LG sliders, originally launched for the Korean market and later internationally.
LG's first GSM phone to be released in the US. Notable for being very thin at the time.
One of LG's first GSM phones to be released in the US. Features an OLED external display and MMS.
A basic candybar phone launched in 2003, having a colour screen and 16 poly ringtones.
A light-weight LG phone featuring a camera and J2ME.
LG's first phone to be released in the US. A basic phone with 10 ringtones and 99 contacts.
A low-end LG phone, featuring monophonic ringtones and a monochrome display.
LG's first colour screen phone to be released in the US. Also features downloadable J2ME apps.
LG's first camera phone to be released in the US. Also features downloadable J2ME apps.
LG's first CDMA phone with Bluetooth. Also features an internal antenna.
An early phone from LG. Features a large display, web capabilities and two games.
An early phone from LG. Features polyphonic ringtones, but affected by quality issues.
A cancelled LG phone with a rotatable screen for watching TV.
A 3G flip phone from LG. It has a large screen and a front camera for video calls.
An early LG phone featuring polyphonic ringtones and downloadable BREW apps.
A tri-mode CDMA candybar phone that supports high-speed 3G data.
A low-end LG phone, featuring monophonic ringtones and a monochrome display.
A very popular LG phone, supporting downloadable graphics, ringtones and apps.
A stylish LG clamshell phone which supports high-speed data and downloadable apps.
LG's first push-to-talk phone, featuring a prominent speaker for making calls.
A mid-range LG phone, featuring a large 18-bit display and OLED external display.
A very popular LG phone, sporting a camera with both a flash and lens cover, as well as analogue roaming.
LG's first video phone to be released in the US.
LG's first 1xEV-DO phone to be released in the US. Also features a 1MP camera and stereo sound.
A small LG CDMA phone. The keypad opens up to reveal a large touchscreen.
A Verizon LG phone that can be opened to a laptop form factor with a QWERTY keyboard.
One of the first mobile phones with 3G, which adds support for video calling.
A Motorola touchscreen phone with A-GPS and microSD card support.
A cheap and basic Motorola phone with long battery life.
A basic dual-band GSM phone made by Motorola. It has an unusual softkey layout.
A Windows Mobile device by Motorola, featuring a QWERTY keyboard.
The best selling flip phone of all time, with over 130 million units sold.
An upgraded version of the RAZR V3 with a higher resolution camera and display.
A candybar phone developed in collaboration with Apple to include the iTunes music player.
A multimedia focused Motorola phone, successor of the ROKR E1 "iTunes phone".
A GSM version of the iconic StarTAC series, equipped with a graphic LCD display.
A popular flip phone made by Motorola.
A well known Motorola flip phone which has an external display and a VGA camera.
A Motorola phone with a small laptop form factor and WAP support.
One of the few i-mode phones sold outside of Japan by NEC.
A low-end basic phone, and the best selling phone of all time, with over 250 million units sold.
An entry level phone with support for GPRS data connections and J2ME applications.
A popular phone which has gained a reputation for being very durable.
A phone featuring new technologies like polyphonic ringtones, J2ME applications, and a colour screen.
A Nokia smartphone with a camera and unique rotary style keypad.
Nokia's first phone with changeable covers, and one of the first with the popular Snake game.
A music oriented slider with buttons dedicated for music features.
A very influential phone with lots of new features like infrared and an ARM processor.
A flip phone with a camera on the side, a predecessor of the N90 camcorder phone.
A popular Nokia smartphone which popularized camera phones.
A Nokia phone with J2ME support, a business oriented version of the 7210.
A Nokia phone with J2ME support, a fashion oriented version of the 6610.
A high-end colour screen phone. Also Nokia's first camera phone, and the first phone with the Series 60 UI.
A never released prototype of the Nokia 7710 touchscreen multimedia phone.
An early touchscreen Nokia phone with strong multimedia capabilities.
The second Nokia Communicator device, supports some DOS applications.
Part of the "Communicator" line of business phones, and Nokia's first phone with WiFi.
A gaming phone by Nokia with a weird design. It was a commercial failure.
The first phone in the Nseries, a series of high-end multimedia phones, along with the N90.
The first Nseries phone along with the N70. Features a camcorder style design and a high-resolution display.
A PDA smartphone with a QWERTY keyboard and a large touchscreen.
A successor to Palm's Treo 600 with a higher resolution display, removable battery and Bluetooth.
A very compact and lightweight Panasonic phone with polyphonic ringtones.
One of the first Panasonic phones with a colour screen, also has polyphonic ringtones.
A Panasonic phone with a tall screen featuring coloured backlighting.
The smallest camera flip phone in the world.
One of the later Philips phones. Has support for contact images.
An early touchscreen phone from Philips, also with a physical T9 keyboard.
A color screen candybar phone made by Philips. It has an interesting D-pad layout.
A compact candybar Philips phone with mobile internet support.
A flip phone from Philips with a 1.3 megapixel camera.
A stylish clamshell phone featuring multimedia controls on the flip cover and 3G connectivity.
A candybar phone made by Sagem, with features like infrared and Java app support.
Samsung's first phone with both CDMA and GSM. Only launched on Verizon, and on China Unicom as the W109.
A small silver flip phone with a twistable screen. Launched in Korea as the SCH-V600.
The Chinese equivalent of the SPH-A800, with a different UI, sounds, synth, etc.
A compact Samsung phone with a pop-up display. Also supports downloadable applications.
A thin, basic flip phone with a widget based UI called Celltop.
A early Samsung flip phone with infrared and a blue backlit LCD. It won a design award.
With a high resolution camera and display, this is Samsung's first phone to sell over a million.
Successor of the D500 with an improved camera and support for TV output.
Successor of the D600, and the thinnest slider phone at the time, at only 13 mm.
A cheaper version of the D900 with a lower screen and camera resolution.
A popular flip phone by Samsung.
A Samsung smartphone running Windows Mobile, and the first ever phone with a hard drive.
A Windows Mobile device with a QWERTY keyboard, also known as Samsung BlackJack.
A stylish Samsung phone with a twisting screen and 3D game support.
A popular flip phone by Samsung, one of the first with a colour screen.
A mid-range clamshell phone by Samsung.
A 3G flip phone from Samsung, commonly found on Vodafone.
A basic clamshell style phone featuring push to talk.
The first 2-megapixel camera phone in the US. Also supports stereo sound and J2ME.
A thin Samsung flip phone which has a swiveling camera and EV-DO data support.
The first PDA phone in the US with a colour screen.
A PDA flip phone with Palm OS, a handwriting recognition pad, and GPS support.
A mid-range Sanyo flip phone which features a VGA camera and downloadable apps.
The first ever phone with a 2MP camera, also featuring a twisting screen and external display.
The first Japanese mobile phone with a built-in camera. It also had a colour screen.
A popular Siemens phone with a WAP browser.
A mid-range phone by Siemens with J2ME support and a VGA camera.
The first phone with a colour screen, being able to display three colours. Also supports voice recording.
A business oriented Siemens phone with multimedia features.
The only Siemens phone running Nokia's Symbian Series 60 platform. Has a unique keypad design.
The sixth phone in the Xelibri fashion series. It has a unique design with two mirrors.
The last Xelibri phone. It was a failure due to being expensive and difficult to use.
A lightweight phone from Sony, one of the earliest phones with polyphonic ringtones.
A small Sony phone meant for one-handed use.
A high-end camera phone by Sony Ericsson with J2ME support.
The successor of the K700 with a better 2 megapixel camera and expandable storage.
A high-end Sony Ericsson phone with a 3.2 megapixel camera and 3D graphics acceleration.
A phone which can be used with both a keypad and a touch screen, similar to the Ericsson R380.
A flagship smartphone by Sony Ericsson, successor of the P900, adding features like Wi-Fi.
A high-end Sony Ericsson phone whose swivel design resembles Japanese phones.
A compact and very basic Sony Ericsson phone with WAP support and preloaded games.
A basic colour screen phone with downloadable games, and the first Sony Ericsson with polyphonic ringtones.
A popular Sony Ericsson phone with a camera, polyphonic ringtones, and J2ME support.
A music oriented phone, and Sony Ericsson's first phone to use the Walkman branding.
A high end flip phone made by Sony Ericsson, equipped with J2ME support and two cameras.
A Japanese flip phone with a large colour screen. Features a unique outer display consisting of 9 LEDs.
One of the first smartphones launched on Movistar. It has a unique sliding keypad design.
A candybar phone by a Spanish company called Vitelcom. It was only available on Movistar Spain.
A candybar phone by the Spanish company Vitelcom. Supports the obscure app format ExEn.
A candybar Vitelcom phone with i-mode compatibility. Also known as the Grundig G342i.
